questions.text: Which of the following parameters is not indicative of reference Indian adult woman?
questions.solution:
According to the 2020 guidelines of the National Institute of Nutrition, the weight of the reference Indian adult woman is 55 kg.

Related Pearl: Reference Indian Man and Woman

Parameters Reference Indian adult man   Reference Indian adult woman  - non pregnant, non lactating
Age 19-39 years   19-39 years  
Weight  65kg  55 kg 
Height  1.77m  1.62m 
BMI  20.75 20.95

questions.text: The energy required by an adult for basal metabolism is:
questions.solution: The energy required by an adult for basal metabolism is 1 kcal/ hour/ kg of body weight.

questions.text: What is the likely energy requirement of a pregnant woman who leads a moderately active lifestyle?
questions.solution:
The energy requirement of a pregnant woman who leads a moderately active lifestyle is around 2500 kcal/day.

An adult woman leading a moderately active lifestyle requires 2130 kcal daily and an additional 350 kcal is needed in pregnancy. Hence, the total requirement for a moderately working pregnant woman is 2480 kcal/ day (approximately 2500 kcal/ day).

Dietary Reference Intakes

  • Recommended Dietary Allowance (RDA) - The average daily dietary intake that is sufficient to meet the requirements of almost all individuals in a group
  • Estimated Average Requirement (EAR) - A nutrient intake value that is estimated to meet the requirements of half the individuals in a group

The EAR for an elderly male (>60 years) is 1700 Kcal/D and for an elderly female (>60 years) is 1500 Kcal/D.

Note: There is no RDA for energy. The EAR is equivalent to Estimated Energy Requirement (EER).

questions.text: A nutritionist is preparing a meal plan for a healthy 32-year-old man. Which of the following principles must she follow?

choices.text: Proteins must constitute 15-30% of the daily energy  intake
Fats must constitute 10-15% of the daily energy intake
Carbohydrate requirement must be met first followed by protein and fat
The proportion of nutrients in the diet must be carbohydrates > fats > proteins

questions.solution:
The proportion of nutrients in the diet must be carbohydrates > fats > proteins.

While constructing a balanced diet, nutrient requirements must be calculated in the following sequence:

  1. Protein requirements - 10-15% of daily energy intake
  2. Fat requirement - 15-30% of daily energy intake
  3. Carbohydrates - remaining food energy

questions.text: What is the daily requirement of high-quality protein for a 40-year-old man weighing 60 kgs?
questions.solution:
This man requires 50 g/day of high-quality protein.

High-quality protein refers to proteins containing all the essential amino acids. According to the FAO/WHO 2007 guidelines, the recommended high-quality protein intake for adult men and women is 0.83 g/kg/day. This man weighs 60 kgs. Hence he requires around 50 g (0.83*60 = 49.8) of high-quality protein per day.

Recommended high-quality protein intake by FAO/WHO:

Age Protein in g/kg/day
1-5 years 0.94
6-10 years 0.91
Adolescent male 0.88
Adolescent female 0.86
Adult man/woman 0.83

However, the mixed Indian diet does not meet the requirement for high-quality protein. Hence, the protein requirement in Indian adults (men and women) is 1g/kg/day of mixed Indian diet protein according to the ICMR 2010 guidelines.

questions.text: A dietary protein-energy percentage of which of the following is the threshold for inadequate protein intake?
questions.solution:
Dietary protein-energy percentage (PE %) < 4% indicates inadequate protein intake. The PE % indicates the proportion of total energy in the diet that is derived from proteins.

PE % = (Energy from protein / Total energy in the diet) * 100

Some of the food items and their protein-energy percentage are given below:

Food PE%
Fish 80
Cow milk 20
Dal 24
Rice 8
Potato 6
Banana 4
Tapioca 2

questions.text: Which of the following is the best indicator of protein quality?

choices.text: Protein digestibility corrected amino acid score

questions.solution:
Digestible indispensable amino acid score (DIAAS) is the best indicator for protein quality.

DIAAS reflects the digestibility of individual amino acids in the protein. Total protein digestibility does not always reflect the digestibility of individual dietary indispensable amino acids. Hence, DIAAS has replaced the PDCAAS (protein digestibility corrected amino acid score) as the preferred index for the evaluation of protein quality.

Related Pearl: Assessment of Protein

Protein quality: Assessed by comparing with reference protein i.e egg protein.

  • Amino acid score:
  • Net protein utilization

A) Amino acid score: It is a measure of the concentration of each essential amino acid in the protein to be tested, expressed as a percentage of that amino acid in the reference protein.

 Digestible indispensable amino acid score (DIAAS) is the best indicator of protein quality. It is defined as follows:

B) Net protein utilization: It is a product of digestibility coefficient and biological value divided by 100. 

Protein quantity: It is assessed by protein energy ratio.

questions.text: Which of the following has the highest net protein utilization value?
questions.solution:
Among the given options, meat has the highest net protein utilization (NPU).

The NPU values of various food items in descending order are: 

  • Egg - 100
  • Meat - 80
  • Milk - 75
  • Rice - 65
  • Soya - 61

Low NPU indicates a high protein requirement. The NPU of Indian diets is usually between 50 and 80.

Related Pearl: Assessment of Protein

Protein quality: Assessed by comparing with reference protein i.e egg protein.

  • Amino acid score:
  • Net protein utilization

A) Amino acid score: It is a measure of the concentration of each essential amino acid in the protein to be tested, expressed as a percentage of that amino acid in the reference protein.

 Digestible indispensable amino acid score (DIAAS) is the best indicator of protein quality. It is defined as follows:

B) Net protein utilization: It is a product of digestibility coefficient and biological value divided by 100. 

Protein quantity: It is assessed by protein energy ratio.

questions.text: A farmer has been consuming a maize-rich diet for many years. Which of the following would be lacking in his diet?
questions.solution:
His diet would be lacking lysine and tryptophan as maize is deficient in these amino acids.

 Principal Food   Amino acid Deficient
Cereals (in general)  Lysine 
Maize   Lysine and Tryptophan 
Wheat  Lysine and Threonine 
Pulses (Poor man’s meat)  Methionine and cysteine 

National Nutrition Week is celebrated from September 1st to 7th every year, promoting the importance of a well-balanced diet. The theme for this year is - 'Celebrate A World Of Flavours'. The aim is to make people have adequate nutrition in food while enjoying the different flavours and cuisine.

questions.text: Which of the following has the highest content of essential fatty acids?
questions.solution:
Safflower oil contains the highest content of essential fatty acids.

Linoleic acid is the most important essential fatty acid.

Dietary source  % content of linoleic acid 
Safflower oil  75
Corn oil  50 
Sunflower oil  62
Soybean oil  53 

Milk is also rich in linoleic acid and oleic acid.

questions.text: You are counseling a diabetic patient to consume foods with low glycemic index. Which of the following would you advise him to eat?
questions.solution:
The patient should be advised to eat whole grains since it has a low glycemic index (GI).

GI is a number representing the relative ability of a carbohydrate food to increase the level of glucose in the blood. It is calculated by comparing the test carbohydrate to the standard (glucose or white bread). This measure has practical use in the management of diabetes and obesity.

  • Low GI foods – most fruits and vegetables, whole grains, pasta foods, beans, and lentils.
  • Moderate GI foods – sucrose, basmati rice, and brown rice.
  • High GI foods – corn flakes, baked potatoes, white bread, potatoes, watermelon, candies, and syrupy foods.

questions.text: The renal feed of a patient suffering from end-stage renal disease (stage 5) should ideally be:
questions.solution:
The renal feed of a patient suffering from end-stage renal disease should ideally be low volume, high calories.

Dietary factors may have an effect on the progression of kidney disease and its complications. A low-volume feed is preferred in order to avoid:

  • Sodium and volume overload
  • Hyperkalemia
  • Hyperphosphatemia
  • Accumulation of toxic metabolites of protein degradation

A high-calorie feed is preferred in order to combat the patient's risk of malnutrition and wasting seen in ESRD.

questions.text: Which of the following is not used in the assessment of body fat?
questions.solution:
Breslow's staging is used for the staging of malignant melanoma, not for the assessment of body fat.

Related Pearl: Indicators for Body fat

The indicators for body fat are:

Body weight: +3SD (standard deviations) from the median weight for height as a cut-off point for obesity. For adults, some people calculate various other indicators such as:

  • Body mass index (Quetelet's index): Weight (kg) / Square of height in metres
  • Ponderal index: Weight (kg)/Height^3 (m)
  • Corpulence index: Actual weight /desirable weight.(Should not exceed 1.2)

Broca's index = Height (cm) - 100 . 

Lorentz's formula 
Ht (cm) - 100 - [ (Ht (cm) - 150) / 2 for women or 4 for men ]

Skinfold thickness: Four sites mid-triceps, biceps, subscapular and suprailiac regions. The sum of the measurements should be less than 40 mm in boys and 50 mm in girls.

Waist circumference and waist-hip ratio: At the mid point between the lower border of the rib cage and the iliac crest. There is an increased risk of metabolic complications for men with a waist circumference~ 102 cm, and women with a waist circumference~ 88 cm. A high WHR (> 1.0 in men and> 0.85 in women) indicates abdominal fat accumulation.

Total body water

Total body potassium

Body density

questions.text: In the Indian population, individuals with BMI falling between which range are defined as overweight?
questions.solution:
In the Indian (Asian) population, a BMI of 23-24.99 is classified as overweight.

However, in the global population, a BMI of 25-29.99 is considered overweight.

Related Pearl: Body mass index

Recent update for Asian population:

Classification Global population (kg/m2)

Overweight 25-29.99 23-24.99 (and At risk)
Obesity >30 >25
Class I obesity 30.0-34.9  25- 29.9
Class II Obesity 35.0 to 39.9  >30
Class III Obesity (severe, extreme, massive) ≥40  

Note:

Lethal BMI:

BMI Value of 13 is considered as “Lethal” in men.

Females withstand and survive even at lower BMI rate upto 11.

questions.text: What value of BMI is considered as 'lethal' in men?
questions.solution:
A body mass index (BMI) of 13 or less is considered lethal in men.

However, females can survive even at a lower BMI up to 11.

questions.text:
Which of the following indicators are used in Waterlow’s classification?
  1. Weight for age
  2. Height for age
  3. Weight for height
  4. BMI for age
  5. Head circumference for age
questions.solution:
Waterlow’s classification makes use of height for age (HFA) and weight for height (WFH) to assess the nutritional status of children.

HFA indicates stunting and denotes the chronicity of malnutrition. On the other hand, WFH indicates wasting and denotes the severity of malnutrition.

The Gomez classification uses weight for age as an indicator of nutritional status. The disadvantage is that it is difficult to determine whether the low weight is due to an acute attack of malnutrition or chronic undernutrition.
